title: 16 Indiana high school students were mistakenly injected with insulin during tuberculosis skin test
text:
Sixteen Indiana high school students were hospitalized on Monday after they were mistakenly injected with insulin during a tuberculosis (TB) skin test, school officials say.

The students are all in biomedical and health science courses at McKenzie Center for Innovation & Technology in Indianapolis.

'In order to do their service in the field, they have to have their TB tests and flu shots on file so that's why they were getting them to begin with,' Dr Dana Altemeyer, spokesperson for the Metropolitan School District of Lawrence Township, told DailyMail.com

After personnel from Community Health Network, which gave the tests, realized what happened, the teenagers were taken to area hospitals.

Dr Altemeyer said that all of the students were in good condition by Monday evening and were discharged

Sixteen students at McKenzie Center for Innovation & Technology in Indianapolis, Indiana, were accidentally injected with a a 'small dosage' of insulin on Monday during a TB skin test (file image)

The district says it's working closely with Community Health Network 'to determine the cause of the error.'

'We have full confidence that the events of today are isolated in nature and will be addressed swiftly by the Community Health Network,' Dr Altemeyer said in a statement.

The tuberculosis skin test is performed by injecting a tiny amount of fluid - 0.1 milliliter - called tuberculin just below the skin in the forearm.

A resulting bump is checked two or three days for any signs of latent or active tuberculosis infection.

It's unclear how personnel mixed up vials of tuberculin with insulin.

Insulin is a hormone that the body produces to get glucose from the bloodstream into cells.

It is often administered via injection to people suffering from diabetes to regulate blood sugar levels.

However, insulin injections can kill non-diabetics by dropping blood sugar levels to dangerously low levels.

Parent Lucille Knowles told FOX 59 that her daughter was one of the affected students and that the teen texted her a picture of a red bump on her arm.

Knowles said her daughter felt cold and shaky, and she was taken to Community Hospital East for observation and five hours of blood sugar testing .

'You have to know what you're doing,' Knowles told WXIN. 'You've got people's lives in your hands. Because they could have died; my daughter could have died. So yes, I'm very angry.'

Questions about the mix-up were directed to Community Health Network, which did not reply immediately to DailyMail.com's request for comment.

However the company released a statement saying it is committed to patient safety and values relationships and partnerships and 'consider[s] it a privilege to partner with schools including MSD of Lawrence Township.'
description: Sixteen students at McKenzie Center for Innovation & Technology in Indianapolis, Indiana, were accidentally injected with a a 'small dosage' of insulin on Monday.
authors: Mary Kekatos Health Reporter For Dailymail.Com
